title: Allowing foreign graduates to work a short-term solution to skilled worker shortage, says Zafrul
summary: The proposal to allow foreign graduates of local institutes of higher education to work temporarily in the country in certain fields, such as the high-tech sector, could further boost Malaysia's education sector as an income generator for the country.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Feb 3): The proposal to allow foreign graduates of local institutes of higher education to work temporarily in the country in certain fields, such as the high-tech sector, could further boost Malaysia's education sector as an income generator for the country.

Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Datuk Seri Zafrul Abdul Aziz said that this year, foreign students in Malaysia are estimated to spend RM7.3 billion a year.

title: Umno says it respects decision of Pardons Board on Najib
summary: Umno says it respects the decisions and absolute discretionary right of the Pardons Board in reducing the jail term and fine against former prime minister Datuk Seri Najib Razak.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Feb 3): Umno says it respects the decisions and absolute discretionary right of the Pardons Board in reducing the jail term and fine against former prime minister Datuk Seri Najib Razak.

This was reached in a special meeting of the party’s Supreme Council chaired by party president Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi at Menara Dato' Onn here on Saturday.

"We respect the decisions and absolute discretionary&

title: Respect Pardons Board's decision, refrain from commenting on social media, says Fahmi
summary: Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil has called on all parties to respect the decision by the Pardons Board on former prime minister Datuk Seri Najib Razak and refrain from making comments on the matter, including on social media.
content:
KUANTAN (Feb 3): Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil has called on all parties to respect the decision by the Pardons Board on former prime minister Datuk Seri Najib Razak and refrain from making comments on the matter, including on social media.

Citing Article 42 (1) of the Federal Constitution, he said, it stipulates that the Yang di-Pertuan Agong has the power to decide on the matter and that the decision cannot be questioned in court.

"If the matter ca

title: Escaped detainees now searching for food, 10 recaptured so far, says Immigration DG
summary: The Immigration Department confirmed that 10 illegal immigrants who escaped from the Bidor Temporary Immigration Centre on Thursday night had been recaptured as of Saturday morning.
content:
TAPAH (Feb 3): The Immigration Department confirmed that 10 illegal immigrants who escaped from the Bidor Temporary Immigration Centre on Thursday night had been recaptured as of Saturday morning.

Immigration director general Datuk Ruslin Juson said the operation to track down the remaining 120 immigrants is ongoing until all of them are apprehended.

“At about 7am today, two individuals were detained at the Batu Melintang Mosque, where they came to seek wat

title: More than 500 foreigners rounded up in op at Seri Kembangan wholesale market
summary: An attempt by two Bangladeshi men, who had been hiding in a drain for two hours, to avoid arrest failed when they were caught in an operation by the Immigration Department at the Selangor Wholesale Market in Seri Kembangan here early on Saturday.
content:
SERDANG (Feb 3): An attempt by two Bangladeshi men, who had been hiding in a drain for two hours, to avoid arrest failed when they were caught in an operation by the Immigration Department at the Selangor Wholesale Market in Seri Kembangan here early on Saturday.

Selangor Immigration director Khairrul Aminus Kamaruddin, who participated in the operation, said a total of 530 foreigners consisting of 504 men and 26 women were rounded up during the operation.

title: CPO futures to trade with upward bias next week on weak output
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: The crude palm oil (CPO) futures contract on Bursa Malaysia Derivatives is likely to trade with an upward bias next week due to weak output, which may lower the overall stock level in the country.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: The crude palm oil (CPO) futures contract on Bursa Malaysia Derivatives is likely to trade with an upward bias next week due to weak output, which may lower the overall stock level in the country.

Palm oil trader David Ng expects the futures prices to trade between RM3,750 and RM3,900 per tonne.

title: Bursa expected to continue upbeat momentum in coming week
summary: Bursa Malaysia is expected to continue its positive momentum next week, amid cautious sentiment on regional and global markets, dealers said.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Feb 3): Bursa Malaysia is expected to continue its positive momentum next week, amid cautious sentiment on regional and global markets, dealers said.

Rakuten Trade Sdn Bhd equity research vice-president Thong Pak Leng said the valuation of the FBM KLCI remains attractive, with the benchmark index having successfully maintained above the 1,500-point mark after surpassing this resistance level last week.

title: Ringgit seen trading range-bound with slight appreciation versus US dollar next week
summary:
The ringgit is expected to trade range-bound with a slight appreciation against the US dollar next week, said an analyst.

Bank Muamalat Malaysia Bhd chief economist Dr Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid said the ringgit is anticipated to trade between 4.71 and 4.72 to the US dollar as investors digest the US non-farm payroll data on Friday.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Feb 3): The ringgit is expected to trade range-bound with a slight appreciation against the US dollar next week, said an analyst.

Bank Muamalat Malaysia Bhd chief economist Dr Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid said the ringgit is anticipated to trade between 4.71 and 4.72 to the US dollar as investors digest the US non-farm payroll data on Friday.

In the meantime, he said the International Monetary Fund had revised its 2024 global growth foreca

title: Ringgit hits new all-time low of 3.5418 against Singapore dollar
summary: Faiqah KamaruddinKUALA LUMPUR: The ringgit hit a new low of 3.5418 against Singapore dollar yesterday compared to the previous record of 3.5333 on Jan 23.The Singapore dollar has appreciated by about 60 per cent against the ringgit in the last 20 years when S$1 ...
content:
Faiqah Kamaruddin

KUALA LUMPUR: The ringgit hit a new low of 3.5418 against Singapore dollar yesterday compared to the previous record of 3.5333 on Jan 23.

The Singapore dollar has appreciated by about 60 per cent against the ringgit in the last 20 years when S$1 was equivalent to RM2.24.

title: UWC sets sights on next chip up cycle
summary: In the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic, Penang-based UWC Bhd stood as one of Bursa Malaysia’s most valuable technology firms, with an impressive market capitalisation of nearly RM8 billion.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Feb 3): In the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic, Penang-based UWC Bhd stood as one of Bursa Malaysia’s most valuable technology firms, with an impressive market capitalisation of nearly RM8 billion.

In 2020 and 2021, the global chip shortage had pushed share prices of semiconductor and semiconductor-related stocks up, including that of UWC’s — an integrated engineering solutions provider — to historic highs.

title: Oil posts weekly losses as US data dents rate cut hopes
summary: Oil prices fell by about 2% on Friday and posted weekly losses after US jobs data shrank the odds of imminent interest rate cuts in the world's largest economy, which could dampen crude demand.
content:
Brent crude futures settled at US$77.33 a barrel, shedding US$1.37, or 1.7%. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at US$72.28 a barrel, falling US$1.54, or 2%.

NEW YORK: Oil prices fell by about 2% on Friday and posted weekly losses after US jobs data shrank the odds of imminent interest rate cuts in the world's largest economy, which could dampen crude demand.

title: S&P 500 surges to record closing high on earnings, robust data
summary: US stocks ended sharply higher on Friday and the S&P 500 registered an all-time closing high as strong earnings and a blowout January employment report boosted confidence in the economy, even while lowering the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates any time soon.
content:
The S&P 500 climbed 1.07% to end the session at 4,958.61 points. The Nasdaq gained 1.74% to 15,628.95 points, while the Dow rose 0.35% to 38,654.42 points. — Reuters

title: Wall St Week Ahead: Robust US data throws off Fed cut narrative
summary: Robust US economic data is confronting investors with an unexpected question: whether strong growth can keep driving stocks higher even if the Federal Reserve delivers less monetary-policy easing than the market had hoped.
content:
Market expectations of a near-term rate cut dimmed after the jobs data.

NEW YORK: Robust US economic data is confronting investors with an unexpected question: whether strong growth can keep driving stocks higher even if the Federal Reserve delivers less monetary-policy easing than the market had hoped.

title: Salary trends
summary: THOSE who intend to stay in their current jobs can possibly expect salary increments hovering around 4% this year, same as in 2023.
content:
THOSE who intend to stay in their current jobs can possibly expect salary increments hovering around 4% this year, same as in 2023.

Those who want to move within the sphere of emerging technologies can expect substantial salary increases, ranging from 15% to 35%, depending on their skills and experience.

Randstad expects robust hiring activities across the board in 2024, but not similar to 2022.

content:
Westports registered record container volume of 10.88 million TEUs in its fourth quarter.

summary: The stock market is a congregation of diverse ideas from people of varying backgrounds.
content:

title: Bursa Malaysia’s quest for a bullish year
summary: As the US Federal Reserve (Fed) hints at an impending interest rate cut, the spotlight intensifies on Asian equities as potential havens for global funds.
content:
AS the US Federal Reserve (Fed) hints at an impending interest rate cut, the spotlight intensifies on Asian equities as potential havens for global funds.

The big question then arises: Can Malaysia secure a slice of this pie, or is it already on the radar of international investors?

title: Gamble on US commercial property blows up for Japan’s Aozora
summary: Aozora Bank Ltd was in a bind in its home market.
content:
The bank stunned the market by setting aside 32.4 billion yen to deal with bad loans. — Bloomberg

AOZORA Bank Ltd was in a bind in its home market.

The Tokyo-based firm was tiny compared with the megabanks that dominate the nation’s financial industry and lacked the well-defined customer base of regional lenders. So about 10 years ago, it decided to expand aggressively overseas, to the point where nearly

title: Weighed by huge debt burden
summary: Malaysia has long had to contend with the issue of rising public debt in recent years.
content:
MALAYSIA has long had to contend with the issue of rising public debt in recent years.

As at end-August 2023, the total federal government debt stood at RM1.15 trillion or 62% of gross domestic product (GDP), below the stipulated debt ceiling of 65% of GDP.
